prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Motion practice before the Panel is much the same as before any other federal court. The Panel Rules require, much like the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, that “[a]ll requests for action by the Panel shall be made by written motion.”[1] The form of motion and other facets of motion practice before the Panel are governed by the Panel Rules.[2]

Although the Panel Rules give particular attention to motions for transfer and remand, the Panel can entertain any other motion. As indicated, for example, in the following section, motions to extend time limits are specifically provided for by the Panel Rules. The only limitation on motion practice before the Panel comes from the limited power or jurisdiction of the Panel.[3] The Panel cannot, for example, entertain a motion relating to management of the transferred cases.

The Panel has considered motions to dismiss motions for transfer.[4] The distinction between dismissal of a motion for transfer and denial of it is not clear, however, and such a motion is not an important procedural tool.

The appearance of an amicus curiae in Panel practice is not a frequent occurrence, but in an appropriate case the Panel may accept an amicus brief.[5] The Panel rules do not specifically address amicus briefs, but a motion seeking leave to serve as amicus should be sufficient if it addresses the questions set forth in the appellate rules for an amicus brief: “the movant's interest; and the reason why an amicus brief is desirable and why the matters asserted are relevant to the disposition of the case.”[6]

The Panel is more likely to consider motions that relate to the nature of the Panel proceedings. In appropriate circumstances, therefore, a motion for an accelerated briefing schedule or special hearing date may be considered. It should be obvious that these motions would not be considered favorably in routine cases, but in a case presenting unusual need for such relief, the motions would be available. A party might, for example, seek to have the caption of an MDL docket changed, although the Panel will not take that step just because a party seeks it.[7]

Most of the Panel Rules establish procedures that apply unless otherwise ordered by the Panel. A request to have any special procedure apply by order should be made in the form of written motion. These motions are governed by a separate Panel rule, permitting action by the Clerk of the Panel and allowing that action without waiting for a response from other parties.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Compare J.P.M.L. R. 6.1 with Fed. R. Civ. P. 7(b).
See Panel Rules 3.2(a) (form of papers) and 6.1 (motion practice).
